comment: It is still a hidden gem. Not many people knew this place, just yet. However, the crowd for a Tuesday evening is not bad at all. We arrived at 7pm and there were already a few tables occupied. I must say that I quite like the place because it feels like Ubud, in Bali sans the paddy field. You can see the crane tower from Interlace! We ordered our favourite Duck Pizza & chicken wings that came with wine (Happy Hour).A new dish to us was seafood aglio olio ($18). It is not bad, but for the price we paid, I will go for another round of duck pizza ($20). Thank you.Another plus point is Shili & Adi perform on Tuesday night. Thus, we were there. Great company for the night. Yes, I will go back again.

Not bike-friendly, thus out of sync with modernSingapore. We arrived on bikes and were made to feel very unwelcome, with lots of surly glares and demands that we leave our (expensive) bikes outside when they have a huge lawn with plenty of space inside. They cited the safety of children... yet they have huge blower fans presumably with spinning blades inside. Not a stop on your next cycling adventure. In the end we put our bikes where they asked - which obstructed entry for everyone else. Idiotic.

Popped by for a pre-exhibition snack, i.e.: the much raved-about thin-crust roasted duck pizza topped with crispy popiah skin w/ drizzles of hoisin sauce. It was absolutely pathetic and this is me trying my best to be diplomatic. Duck slices were few in number, tough, badly seasoned and extemely gag-inducing. Hoisin sauce tasted more like teriyaki with too much sugar mixed in. Crust was soft and completely soggy in all areas apart from the sides. The most hilarious part of this experience happened after we left. Requested to doggy bag the remains of our pizza (which was simply too unappetizing to finish) and they came back with something resembling a foil ball. Okay. Upon opening it at home, we found the remaining slices squished into a dough ball whose center contained the soggy flaps of what once was "crispy" popiah skin. Only redeeming feature would be the bouncy castles. Go if you have hyperactive children and like talking to waiters that hate their lives.

do not make the same mistake we all made when driving here.do enter from alexandra rd into malan rd then left onto lock rd.there's a big car park on the left before block 9.parking is free.after which look for block 9A. be warned there's no air con here.it's purely outdoor seating.mosquitoes could be an issue with distinctive smell of mosquito repellent and coil.more fans could be utilized to make for a more cooling al fresco experience.what impresses me is their use of technology.our table came with ipad with their menu for perusal.once decided you order via the ipad!special request can also be accommodated when putting in your order.happy hour 6-9pm, erdinger beer was 2 pints get 1 pint free at $30.we ordered the timbre platter to start.with garlic prawns, crispy pork belly, beef stew, crab meat mayo bruschetta, nachos with beef salsa and garlic bread.nice presentation and tasted good. crispy pork belly could be crispier though.we also ordered their roast duck pizza.roasted duck breast, sauté shiitake mushroom with hoisin sauce, topped with mozzarella cheese and crispy popiah skin.interesting combo which worked well.more beers.then we ordered the pha ngan & portofino platter..with green seafood curry & foccacia bread, stuffed poached squid, Timbre's shrimp & fish sausages and deviled eggs.predominantly asian flavours here and well assembled.simple timbre chicken wings for those who don't take spiciness well but if you like it hot then the timbre buffalo wings will rub you the right way.their special devil sauce makes the wings black and comes topped with roasted peanuts.their breaded calamari was also ok.the squid rings were thick enough but batter could be thinner.more beers.they have live music and tonight was shili and adi.their microphone or speakers could be a little louder as we could barely make out what they were saying during their sets.what we liked best was the sms way to make a song request.simple and quick.more beers.service was ok.two things needed improvement:1) they brought us our check way before we were ready to call it a night!?one of my friend hasnt even shown up yet!2) 5 orders of happy hour beers was registered but we think we only had 4 rounds of it!no fuss made, they double checked and deducted accordingly.ocbc titanium card holders get priority queue for entry and 10% discount.

Two stars for the lush garden-like outer environment....otherwise impossibly ghetto.   There is loud construction work in the adjacent parking lot that continues into the evening, which pairs tragically well with the dated and low-grade R&B they feature here.  They have live bands most evenings playing the same potpourri of 15-20 or so American songs endlessly recycled by every SG cover band.   Most tables are outdoors, and there are approximately 6 fans total for 70+ tables.  There are 2 reasonably cold draft choices;  $14++ for happy hour.  Service is typical SG - do not expect social graces, manners of any variety, or pride of ownership...staff out number customers yet wander about cluelessly whilst tables wait exagerated period to simply order drinks - we witnessed this pattern with each new customer that entered.  The location has much, much, potential, which the prior tenant, Villa Bali, made very rich use of.  Timbre, however, is best avoided - particularly if you are from the West, it is very likely to disappoint.  Tragic given the potential of the location...

address: Level 1 10 Telok Blangah Green Singapore 109178 Singapore
comment: I am in love with this cafe. Went for dinner at Txa Pinto and they recommended we check out Wildseed in the day, so we did!We sat outdoors by the green gazebo. It was just soooo pretty. The drinks were also good, I had the chai, my friends drinks like the wildseed cafe special drink looked much better/insta worthy. But both tasted great! The food wasn't anything that blew me away, but it's pretty decent. This is the perfect cafe for a brunch catch up with friends or a date. Loooove.

This place has now become my favorite AYCE sushi served to order. Priced right with some gems such as amaebi and outstanding swordfish and hamachi.The only let down was the Gintara that was sullied with cloying sweet sauce.
I like the japanese buffet here but it is not available for one single person. (Sad) the picture is a set lunch, the first listed in the menu. Big portion food for just one person.

As with all buffets, don't expect all items to be winners, but expect a general quality in their items. Sashimi is decent, there's shabu shabu but I'd rather save space for other items. Fried shishamo is good, fried oysters - yum! Tempura was decent, not great, but still not too bad.If you are the kind who goes to Sushi Tei and spends about $50 there and didn't get to eat a large plate of sashimi while there, this place will make it worth your while because you'll get your usual items plus free flow sashimi. Come here for variety and value.Location is rather convenient, with an MRT station close by. Enjoy!

Himawari Japanese Restaurant is one of my favorite japanese buffet places to go to since we have discovered this place years ago.  This restaurant is a hidden gem in the Alexandra office park. Parking is relatively a breeze here. This restaurant is good for crowd and even family oriented.  Their japanese buffet is value for money. They have a wide spread of dishes for one to choose from, ranging from sashimi, maki, tempura, shabu shabu, sukiyaki, teppanyaki,  and much more.  (I think they got more than 80 different selections). In fact, you can top up for an option to have free flow of alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks.  Great for people who love good food and drinks. They have another outlet at Changi Business Park too.

Someone once commented that cereal is like Asian bacon for us. Sprinkle it on anything and it is delicious. Well I fully agree! In fact, shortly after a trip to the nearby Two Chefs' Eating Place, I was introduced to another place near Anchorpoint at Stirling Road with.. Cereal Chicken. I actually don't really eat cereal prawns normally because the prawns are fried and you have to eat it with the shell, which I don't like. So cereal chicken is INGENIOUS!That also makes me, according to my boss, a serial cereal eater. Hur.It was really really good. Barring the fact that we were starving by the time we were there at 9pm after work, the dish stands by its own merits of being so delicious, I kept thinking about it the next day!The chicken is fried and the cereal thrown in to add that sweet savoury taste. It is not too oily - in fact it felt quite light. The chicken was juicy and the cereal complimented the crunchiness of the skin. I could go on and on about how awesome this is. Just go. Try it for yourself!We also ordered 4 other dishes that night. Surprisingly, ALL of them were very very good. I am not kidding. This place does good tze char. The fish (top left) was very fresh and smooth. The hotplate tofu was flavourful and had a lot of ingredients. The egg with "chai po" (some salted vegetable bits) was also full of unami. Lastly the sweet and sour pork was juicy yet not too sour/strong in the sauce which was done just nice.If you are looking for an all-rounded tze char place to go for a family dinner or gathering, try Stirling Seafood. I hope you liked it as much as I do because it is a great place! I am definitely going back to try their other dishes and reorder the Cereal Chicken.

I love the Thai food here. Everything I've tried so far is good. Basil chicken and basil pork are spicy and tasty though they do not have a strong wok hei smell like some other places. Stuffed chicken wing comes hot and is crispy.Olive rice is good here. Likewise for their veggie dishes, simply stir fried with garlic or belachan. The papaya salad is also spicy and refreshing.Tom yum seafood soup (3 versions - clear, original orange and coconut) is tangy and spicy. I have tried both original orange and with coconut and they are equally good. The coconut version will have a bit of creamy taste to it.The green curry chicken is fantastic over plain rice. I have run out of words to describe what I had but so far nothing is awful. For drinks, I prefer the iced thai milk tea over the iced lemongrass. You could ask to doggy bag the leftovers even when the portion is really tiny. It is that good not to be thrown away. The service was efficient and the auntie serving us had typical auntie behavior - making sure our table was ok. It looked like it was going to rain and we were seated outside with no awning over us. She kept asking if we were ok and in the end told us it might be better to move the table in. So she moved it to the walkway outside another shop which was closed for the day. This is definitely not a fine dining place and is a laid back casual eatery with a homely feel to it. You come here for good Thai food in an unpretentious place.

This is a cute Thai restaurant located close to the IKEA. I was expecting it to be very good but I thought the dish I had was just okay in terms of flavor. I also felt like it wasn't as good value as some of the other random shops I've been to.I got the chicken red curry (small) and it was like $7.50 or so. Still cheap by USD standards but I feel like other places would offer the same amount at like half the price or so? I thought the flavor was okay. They had some chicken pieces and some potatoes. Not much meat in a small portion though. I had to pay $1 SGD for okay rice.Also they didn't give me any napkins or water but I think that's pretty typical of most Singaporean eateries.

The idea of dining at Joe's Kitchen had been in my mind for a long time ever since I spotted them while driving along the stretch of road into the AYE (Ayer Rajah Expressway). This thought had recently grew stronger when I saw our local Television Programme advertising its cuisine.One of the recommended dishes, Thai Fish Cake. Most of their "finger food" items were charged based on per piece which was quite different from other thai restaurants. Fish cake was abit oily, however the fish meat was rather fresh and one can feel the bounciness as we sank our teeth in. The salad and sweet sour chilli had complimented the dish well. Luminous yellow pineapple rice with rasins, cashew nuts, pork floss and prawns sum up the plate of  pineapple rice. Taste wise, I felt that it's pretty average, nothing to rave about.The stuff chicken wing was the main highlight among all dishes. Do not worry about eating them with your bare hands and removing the bones. In fact, only the bottom part of the chicken has bone, the rest was stuffed with  goodies.Let's check out their secret recipe in their stuffed chicken wings.The exterior of the wing was fried to crisp golden brown perfection with fillings made up of minced chicken meat mixed together with bits of chestnuts and sweet corn kernels. Uniquely Joe's Kitchen!After the stuff chicken, this is another specialty of Joe's Kitchen that one cannot left the place without. Given a choice of crispy tofu, hotplate and claypot toufu, the server highly recommended the first option. Well, we bought her words and it was great. Just like the stuffed chicken wings, the toufu was specially made, blended with seafood bits and fried over the hot oil. The exterior was very crispy, not too oily and to my liking.How can a Thai Cuisine be without their so called Fresh Thai Coconut and Lemon Grass drink? Ha! These were the beverages for the night.Minced Pork Omelette was nothing special, quite a standard dish.Prawns with cashew nuts was tad spicy as it was cooked with dried chilli and capsicums. Although the portion was medium, the number of prawns given wasn't that much.After the night's dinner, I find that what most interest me was their appetizer or finger food items. They were special and not many Thai Cuisine offers such items on their menu.

A great find! Over a year or two, one friend or the other would mention Joe's Thai and I would resolve to try it. Now regret it took so long to make there! The next visit will be soon! All in all, an experience that puts my older favorite basic Thai restaurants to shame. Among the local - easy parking, easy access from the street, and easy setting - Thai places, I would say I haven't seen better. Until now I would succumb to the continuing lure of E-Sarn from its Sixth Avenue days, even as its food and service continue to sink successively lower across its locations. Finally, no more inertia-driven journeys there. It will be Joe's Thai. The service is warm, friendly, and efficient. There is shared laughter among the wait staff, and an of late rare eagerness to please. I reserved a place for 3. For a very inexpensive restaurant, I was utterly surprised to find the spot properly reserved, with 3 places neatly set with plate, utensils, side bowl and spoon and chopsticks when we arrived! A second server came by to double check that we were the right party!!The portions were generous, and we ordered several small size dishes. And the prices are very reasonable, with small portions ranging from $7-11. The Tom Yum soup with prawn was the most delicious I have had in some time. There is something special to it, but I couldn't tell - and nor would the server who told me, "it is our chef's secret". The red curry was equally outstanding. So were the sweet potato leaf, pineapple rice and fish cake. The excellent basil minced chicken had a slightly darker, thicker sauce than one usual finds at other Thai places, laced with something sour to add to the soy sauce-based preparation. Finally the red ruby dessert and the tapioca were delicious too. If I had to quibble, I'd say the green curry could be spicier, and less thick - no complaints though, this loser dish among the order was very good too! And the red ruby could be slightly (very slightly) less milky. In short, you can't go wrong. Oh, well, yes, you can by gorging excessively! So rush down when you can to tickle your palate. Don't miss the Tom Yum. And skip a meal prior!

Nice quaint place next to Ikea..authentic Thai food and the owner is especially attentive to your needs. Definitely try the Thai Coconut and the mango salad. The sticky rice with mango was absolutely delightful..

My friend 'always takes away Joe's Kitchen', so we did just that. There's never much glamour in taking away stuff from anywhere, least of all a place that looks as simple as Joe's Kitchen. But especially in the food business you can never judge a book by its cover, just as how you should never judge a dinner by the tablecloth.This was indeed very delicious Thai takeaway, quick, fuss free, and inexpensive. The Tom Yum Soup (the clear red sort), when served warm, will most definitely give you a run for your money, if not at least a run for some water. It's packed with spiciness in a very delectable way, such that even me with my low tolerance couldn't resist taking so many spoonfuls of this bad boy. The basil chicken was very fragrant with a very strong taste without being too overwhelming. I like the fact that it's minced, rather than in chunks, as this allows the meat to get coated with sauce. The stuffed chicken was a very interesting dish as well, even if the bits of corn in it turned me off a little, but the size of it was rather generous indeed, and I was happy enough with the one wing I had. We had the fish cake as well, which was a tad pricey, given that it was just rather average. Go for the green curry as well though - it had a good ratio of milk and spice, and the meat in it was very tender and I could just imagine having this accompanied with plain rice.That said, my favourite dish of all was the pineapple rice, which was very tasty, had the right level of sweet, and the right proportion of ingredients. So often they get it wrong with having either too huge chunks of pineapple, or not enough pineapple, or no raisins, or being too oily - but this has it spot on. Definite recommendation in my books.

Checked out Joe's on a cold rainy day, hoping some hot spicy tom yam soup and the like would warm us up. Our experience however, was already marred by the service even before the food arrived at our table.Food: Love the prawn cakes and stuffed chicken wings. Tom yam soup a bit too OTT for my liking. Think I should stick to Indian / Peranakan / Malay /Chinese spicy food and skip Thai spicy and sour stuff. Prawn claypot vermicelli was OK, just annoyed had to keep picking out the bits of garlic.Service: Awful beyond awful. Grumpy old waitress ambled her way up to us and kept banging on about whether we could finish the food. So we asked her if there was a smaller helping. She said no and kept pushing the pad thai but said it was the same size as vermicelli (???). We insisted on trying the vermicelli and she kept pushing the pad thai. ARGH.Ambience: Very stark and bare. Not the most welcoming place in the world.Might just stop by to takeaway the prawn cakes and wings.

Joe's is my go to place for Thai-Chinese food. The kitchen is helmed by Joe, who used to work at a Thai restaurant before starting his own little piece of heaven in Alexandra. Sure the restaurant looks like a coffee shop with air con, but damn the food tastes so good. My dining partner and I eat there at least once a fortnight and our favourite dish hand's down is the Honey Chicken. Its a plate of chicken strips fried really crispy with garlic slices then covered in a thick honey/buttery sauce that I can't quite decipher. It's very addictive and I haven't found this dish at any other Thai restaurant and will absolutely die if anything happens to Joe. His tom yam soup is also wonderfully piquant with a balance of coconut, chilli and spices and I like the seafood version best. The clay pot crab or prawn vermicelli here is also a knockout as Joe uses lard, so if you're concerned about your health eat rice or something. I also love the prawn cakes, which are made with fresh shrimp and very little filler. The dishes I don't really fancy are the sambal sweet potato leaves (too dry), pad thai (for some reason very flat compared to the Thai vermicelli of the same price) and red wine prawns (sauce is weird). To put it short, Joe's is the type of place you close your eyes and ignore all the non-food related factors and just eat to satiate your Thai cravings. Prices here are also incredibly competitive so I go frequently enough to make sure they don't go out of business ever (not that they need my business)!

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Ok, so this is a 5-star review. Uh-huh. Five stars. And I don't award these lightly. Apart from the simply phenomenal food, what made this such a fantastic experience was the friendly & humorous owners (husband & wife team) with a kind twinkle in their eyes. Sum Kee is a tze char restaurant tucked away in a nondescript building in Telok Blangah. Even our cab driver wasn't 100% sure of the location. But step into their quaint compound and you will be hit by its old skool charm. An old swing sits in their garden, & the interior is kitschy with orange walls. A sign says (paraphrased) "we cook our food fresh. So please wait and eat". You can tell they are quite fun here!On to the food. I'm gonna list the dishes I enjoyed. 1. Ultraman Chicken (咸蛋鸡). This is a salted egg chicken and OMG I die. It is so damn good. It is named after Ultraman because this beloved manga character's Chinese name is literally translated as Salted Egg Superman (咸蛋超人). The witty lady boss really has a wicked sense of wordplay and it bloody works because it is so memorable!!!!2. Beancurd in Pumpkin Gravy. Now, this is not a typical tze char dish in Singapore and you've gotta try it. I love pumpkin soup so this appealed to me greatly. Throw in the fragrant minced pork and hello!!! Winner!!!!3. Salted egg crab, Black Pepper Crab and Chilli Crab. Now, I liked all three. The black pepper crab is actually a little on the sweeter side, which surprisingly still works. My fave is the chili crab -- the gravy is not too sweet and actually is kinda zesty!!! (I usually worry about Chilli crab being too sweet). So I enjoyed the kick. Oooh lala!4. curry Fish head. Now, this curry is not too thick and not like the typical northern indian curry. It is like a Chinese curry - more "lemak" (coconutty). The Red Snapper was very tender and fresh and boy, was it delish!!!! Photo attached!!! Now, if only there is a Scratch & Sniff function in the photo so you can smell its fragrance!!!!5. Cuttlefish with Kang Kong. Their version is very tasty indeed. Oh boy. They throw in generous amounts of crushed peanuts and sesame on top, and it becomes crunchy and yummy and everything just becomes a party in your mouth. 6. Ngor Hiang. They add water chestnut into it and suddenly, it becomes a crunchy delight, and completely elevates this humble dish. 7. Fried Ice Cream. Hands up if you can find fried ice-cream these days. Where. WHERE?!?!? This is old school style which I love. Fried on the outside and lovely cold vanilla ice-cream on the inside. What a splendid way to end a meal. Loves. There are many more dishes I enjoyed (like their Wallet Chicken) but writing a long review on a mobile phone is tough work (and my poor eyes!!!!). So please go to Sum Kee and do try as many dishes as your belly permits. Honestly -- NO REGRETS. Calories gained are absolutely WORTH IT. Reservations are simply a must on weekends. And oh yah, if you need toilet paper, just ask them for it. My tip to you. NOW GO TO SUM KEE!!!!!

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Good Zi Char place. An institution in Singapore - see ieatishoot earliest review. Popcorn chicken was good when paired with BYOB wines ($1.50 per pax corkage charge). Signature fish head curry also worth ordering. My fave were the veggie dishes the French beans & the chives with bean sprouts. XO San Lo hor fan was also tasty.

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Best restaurant especially curry fish head. Came all the way from San Francisco just for this.

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Used to be located at the corner shophouse at zion road hawker. Since the move to its current location at Yeo's building, there's no longer a carpark crunch as there is abundant space now.  carpark space. It has an old school Beer garden feel, reminds u of the old fashioned chinese restaurant in the 80s.What's good here is their golden nugget tofu - homemade tofu deep fried with minced meat gravy, sum lo hor fun (no XO and XO versions) where you can actually taste the wok hei. Their Prawn paste chicken is pretty good as well. Like the ambience. Somewhere u can enjoy the old fashioned surroundings with beer after dinner.

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Family dining off Telok Belangah 31! Inside with AC and al fresco dining Inside has large round tables to easily seat 8. Facilities seasoned (older). Don't expect fancy. But food is tasty.  Great chinese dish selections. Even vegetarian too.  Large variety to choose from. We particularly enjoyed the tofu options. Saw several tables seated with 3-4 generations in the family.   I understand they have a lunch menu too.  Reasonable pricing.  Easy walk to/from the MRT. And, if you elect to drive, FREE parking!

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Other than the usual favourites, we tried their Braised Pork Trotter with Mushroom. I don't fancy pork trotter actually because its usually so fatty!!! But their version is meaty with a good amount of fats! And the sauce is tasty without it being too over-powering. I am now a fan of their pork trotter!!!

address: 2 Telok Blangah St 31 Yeo's Building Singapore 108942 Singapore
comment: Foods not presentable n taste not so good .All our family feel disappointed n hopefully u guys can improved better.Thanks

address: Block 41 Malan Road Gillman Barracks Singapore 109454 Singapore
comment: I had read the Straits Times's article last Sunday, on a showdown of the good old cheeseburger from 12 burger-centric restaurants in Singapore, by a panel of 4 judges: The Sunday Times' senior food correspondent Wong Ah Yoke; Violet Oon Singapore's director of operations Tay Yiming; Artichoke restaurant's chef-owner Bjorn Shen; and The Sunday Times' food editor Tan Hsueh Yun. And BurgerLabo emerged as the clear winner out of the 12 restaurants that were put to the test, which were Hans Im Glück, Omakase Burger, Shake Shack, Wolf Burger, McDonald's, Carl's Junior, Fat Burger, Black Tap at MBS, Burger Joint in Amoy Street, Burger+, and Fat Papas in Bali Lane. Needless to say, I was soooo tempted and intrigued to try it after reading that article. LolSo here I came today, to try the best burgers out of all the famous burgers in Singapore. A little disclaimer though, I'm not those that try every single burger that open up in town. I'm not that into burgers, since I'm health conscious... lol. I know I know, health conscious yet still greedy and all about food, how contradictary. But seriously, what got me intrigued here though, is that BurgerLabo uses a 170g beef patty for their Basic Burger ($23), that is made from a blend of grass-fed Black Angus beef neck, Aomori Gyu ribeye, Toriyama Umami Wagyu A4 tenderloin, and Sendai Wagyu A5 brisket, to get that 'perfect' balance of flavors. The patty is further topped with grilled organic tomato, locally-farmed Green Wave lettuce, 2 slices of American cheese, house-made bone marrow 'butter' and sauce. The bone-marrow butter is used to toast the bread and grill the meat patty. On the special sauce, Mr Tan Ken Loon, owner of the 3 month old BurgerLabo, said: "I love to eat bone-marrow and I wanted to incorporate it into the burger patty. However, the oils will come out and the patty will start to shrink. So instead, I extracted the bone marrow, warmed it into a liquid state and, after it is chilled, it looks like a milky white blob of butter. We don't use oil, we use this."This is the 12th version of Mr Tan's Basic Burger, from when he started on his burger journey in December 2015. BurgerLabo is the sister restaurant to The Naked Finn, which is also owned by Mr Tan. To this much precision and care taken to engineer a perfect beef patty, with the meticulous effort of using organic ingredients and grass-fed beef for the patty to appeal to the ever growing health conscious crowd like me, I'm totally sold and determined to come here to try the burger. So after the long ass background story, so yeah, the burger was AWESOMELY delicious!!! I cannot describe it all in words really, how delicious and melt in your mouth the whole burger was, you really have to just go try it for the experience. Perfectly well balanced and juicy, the patty's charred surface gave it a smoky flavor, without the patty being overcooked, due to it being cooked a la plancha. Cooking the meat on a plancha sears the meat better than any other cooking surface can. It creates a browned, slightly crispy exterior while sealing in all the juices. For those Ramly burger lovers, you can add a fried organic free-range egg with a runny orange yolk to the burger, for an extra $3. The Basic Burger with a single 170g patty is $23, a double patty of 150g each (if I'm not wrong) will costs you $36. Adding an egg to the double patty, the burger will set you back a whopping $39. I was expecting throngs of people rushing to go try this burger out after the article got published in our national papers, but surprisingly I could easily get a table without making a reservation. I guess the location is a little inaccessible if you don't drive and probably not everyone is willing to part with $39 for a burger, since a burger is afterall just a burger. Albeit it was a very well made one. If cost is a factor, just go for the Basic Burger, that is already a very delicious burger imo. But if you have decided to travel all the way JUST for this burger, and you don't live in Singapore, I'll say, go for the double patty with an egg thrown in to get the full experience of that goodness. Hahaa... I've ordered the mid-joint wings, it was good too, nicely marinated but it was kinda tiny and not worth the $12 for that 5 tiny pieces. I have eaten chunkier and juicier wings, price-performance ratio isn't good. I'll suggest you save your money and skip that. Service was fast and friendly. Not a good place for conversation though. So, was the burger worth it? Yes, I would think it was well worth bursting my calories today for it. I will definitely bring my foreign friends visiting Singapore who are craving burgers, to try this place out. So 5 stars for the burger, until I chanced upon another burger that impress me more than this one did. Hope my review will help you in some way to decide if to dump $40 for a burger. Hahaha... I've tried. :)

address: Block 41 Malan Road Gillman Barracks Singapore 109454 Singapore
comment: This was hands down the best burger I have ever had in my life. I've been to countless burger joints in America, but Singapore's BurgerLabo outdoes this western dish by miles!!! I did a walk in when I went at 5:00pm (when they opened), but I would highly recommend you make a reservation, as it seemed like a lot of people reserved a table for later in the day. As for the meal, it was just amazing. I could taste the umami in the A4/A5 wagyu patty with each bite, and the truffle fries were outstanding with a strong truffle flavor. Despite the pretty step price at $23 for the basic burger and $4 for the truffle fries with cheese, the experience is worthit. Do yourself a favor and indulge in this delectable burger! I will for sure be back at BurgerLabo the next time I visit Singapore!

So surprised to find a fantastic Chinese restaurant in this shopping mall. For 5 people we ordered:-1. Century Egg with Vinaigrette & Chili Oil (mixed opinions)*2. Crisp Fried Tofu w/ Salt & Pepper (v popular)3. Wok-Fried Carrot Cake in XO Sauce (okay)-4. Marinated Jellyfish with Vinaigrette (too spicy, small broken up pieces of jellyfish)5. Combination Plate with duck, pork belly and cha shao pork6. Crisp-fried Crystal Prawns tossed with Salted Egg Yolk (delicious)*7. Sweet and Sour Pork (the dish loved by the most people)-8. Poached Marbled Beef in Hot and Spicy Stock (too spicy, don't order again)*9. Stir Fried French Beans with Minced Pork and Preserved Olive Vegetables (delicious)10. Yang Zhou Fried Rice (okay)*11. Wok Fried Hor Fun with Sliced Beef (delicious)Asterisk next to the best dishes, and a minus sign next to the dishes I wouldn't order again. Next time, I want to try ordering dim sum for dinner.

This is a pretty decent Cantonese place. It feels somewhat high class and the prices reflect that (it's closer to $20-$30 SGD / person)The menu is in both English and mandarin. My coworker and I tried a bunch of dishes. Overall I liked it (he was also a fan) although I did think some of the flavors were slightly on the sweet side. They tasted like it would cater to Western (or in my case American specifically) tastes, curiously enough.-black pepper beef: beef was very tender / chewy and sauce was strong. I think I would have liked this dish a tad bit crispier but there might be other beef dishes with different cooking styles-sweet and sour bean dough: fried bean dough yum! Sauce was sweet and a little tangy. Felt super unhealthy though but eat sparingly!-sautéed spinach with garlic: classic can't really go wrong with this if you wanted a leafy salty dish-cold cucumbers in spicy sauce: I usually don't like raw cucumbers but I really liked the spicy sauces. It was slightly hot and numbing which I like in foods!-Hong Kong milk tea: tasty and not overwhelmingly sweet

What a cute Japanese mart! It has some basic convenience store foods but there's also a full blown restaurant in the back too. This place has a lot of refrigerated fish for sale too. I also found that there is a sizable dessert section too and they have my favorite ice cream mochi from Lotte here too, for $3.20 SGD. It's more expensive than in Japan of course but it's still worth it!

Another branch of the Sakuraya fish market. We usually eat at the restaurant only. (They also sell Japanese groceries.)The highlight of the place is choosing your fish from the counter and having it sashimi-ed on the spot. Good quality fish at a great price.The cooked items vary in quality, though I always order the grilled salmon belly - a sinful salt bomb!

Look! Up in the sky!  It's a market.  It's a restaurant.  It's I dunno...both maybe?  You can go pick out fish and take it home to slice and eat or just eat it there.  There's a little Japanese market attached where you can buy little staples you might not be able to find elsewhere (umi paste anyone?).  Me?  I like the pick it and take it home to slice and eat thing.  So ya...I'm a fan.

Order sashimi at the counter and don't just rely on the menu. it will enhance your experience considerably. i love the freshness of the sashimi and how each slice just melts in my mouth. always check with the chef for what's in season and you can customized how you want your fish to be done.

Best curry chicken in Singapore! Great flavor, right spiciness, right thickness. Potato is soft, rice is not clumpy and nicely cooked. The only downside is that the chicken is slightly overcooked. Curry is simply a unique dish that doesn't really rely on the ingredients as much as the sauce. So despite the slightly overcooked curry chicken, it's still the best curry chicken in Singapore.Prices start from $3 including rice or bread. The dollar amount you order would indicate the amount of chicken drumlets or wings given to you. $3 = 3 and $4 = 4 so on. Well, how good is it? Let's just say that it's so good I would even drink the spicy curry on it's own. The queue is perpetually long and you'd have to wait for a while to get seats. Service on the other hand is extremely fast. Within 5 minutes, all your orders would arrive. It simply is the best chicken curry in Singapore!

Would travel all the way from north just to have some of their chicken curry and laksa! Most of the time there's long queue. Their food is worth the travel and wait because they are consistent!Friendly aunties serving with enthusiasm and energy! Looking forward to have my next bowl soon!

The curry chicken here never fails to disappoint. This is our family weekly hangout whenever we don't have a clue what to have for lunch/dinner. However try to avoid during lunch time or there will be a Long queue as seats here are very limited. Staffs here are super friendly and nice too. Love it!

The simple pleasure of bread with curry and a large chicken drumstick to complement the intake of carbohydrates is quite an unforgettable experience. The store is located in the centre of Queensway Shopping Centre, and as the layout of the place constraints the setting up of seats, customers may end up sitting side by side, as if at a sushi counter. The serving is very generous, and even with two pieces of bread( or more, or rice, depending on one's choice), it is quite impossible to finish the huge bowl of curry. The only drawback is that the place is so cramped and busy during meal times, it could be easier to eavesdrop on the loud customers next to you than hear what your companion might be saying. Prices: range from $3-$6. Opening hours: Mon-Sun 9am-8pm.

Jiak Pa Lang?based on the chinese characters in their signage it would mean to eat one's fill.but there is also a similar sounding phrase which means a collection of random items?i have only tried their lunch menu which is based on the concept of salad and rice bowls.a localized version of the western concept or a westernized version of our local chap chye peng?it marries the best of both worlds, in my opinion.high quality gourmet ingredients not commonly found in the local economical rice stalls and delightfully local flavours injected into a normally boring ang mo salad or sometimes overly healthy rice bowl.here, they strike a good balance and is neither too cheap nor too expensive.i would get the value set additions, especially their daily soup, homemade goodness with every sip.it can get crowded and noisy during lunch peak hours.but they try their best to speed up the ordering process with mobile tablets and staff moving down the line of hungry diners to expedite order taking.plentiful aircon seating within and outdoors as well.can be very boisterous and cafeteria like indoors.clean bathrooms and charging points aplenty but do select seats strategically as needed.i have not tried their dinner menu yet as they are only open on weekdays.but from what i read, their innovative creations, or remakes, of local zi char dishes will be what you can expect.if their lunch is a good gauge then i will be in for a palate tantalizing dinner treat when i do find time for a weekday evening meal here!

SO GOOD. Only omakase or set for dinner. Seasonal ingredients, fish flown fresh from Tsukiji Market. Top notch service. Lovely cosy ambience. I can't form complete sentences because the meal was SO GOOD and I am still reeling from it. Even dessert which is usually nothing to shout about, was amazing. Semifreddo, caneles, chocolate truffles. Please come here. Parking available at the Alexis condominium.

Good quality of raw materials from Japan with Italian fusion. Agree with the other reviewer that the place does not have premium location or fancy deco. But the staff there are nice and warm. They offered to split up a six wine pairing to two glasses each (and I'm pretty sure they pour more than they should:) once they heard we are light drinkers only and could prob not each finish six glasses. The food is great- it's creative, tastefully plated, and reminds me of a lot of good memories of having lived in Japan.

I am so sad to review this place so low.....but I can't mince words when the experience was just simply terrible.   Three of us went for lunch, ordering one omakase, one 4 course and one a la carte (simply because of the food allergy).  We each had a glass of Prosecco.  Sounds good, right?   But first amuse bouche comes, mediocre octopus and avocado cup which pretty much tasted like guacamole, then my appetizer, Hiroshima oyster gazpacho, the oyster smelled so awful I couldn't even fish the second one.  Even the granita on the top tasted like frozen ketchup.  Salad on the side was doused with French dressing-ish goo, which tasted like something out of a jar.  Then, the much anticipated uni tagliolini.   A tiny one piece of uni on top, the sauce was not well mixed with pasta, though sauce was good.  I can't really call it a uni pasta if uni is used so little.  Squid ink sauce helped but it needs to use more uni, if you are calling this the famous uni dish.   Aqua Pazza, the main tasted like salty Shiri miso soup with seafood.  Entirely too salty with not so fresh seafood.  It came out to be $298 for three of us and most unsatisfying food.  Oh let's not forget, this place served a frozen baguette that can be ordered via le petit depot, the French grocer.  So so so sad.

I enjoyed a pleasant lunch at The Rabbit Stash, opting for the 2 course set.  It's always inspiring to see young chefs so passionate about food and creating an enjoyable experience for their guests. It felt like we were dining in a private kitchen and as I understand, this stems from Chef Mok's experience in private dining.I really liked the plating, which was elegantly, modern and not too fussy. Simple and clean, with bright, vibrant colours which made the food pop and the ingredients shine.The sea scallop in the appetizer trio was perfectly cooked with a nice sear and I enjoyed the roasted pork belly too. Not too sure about the pickled mushrooms as a complement although I suppose this was meant to whet one's appetite. The iberico ham and foie gras were delicious too and I loved the pan seared "crust" of the foie gras which was crispy, and lovely against the soft liver. The fillet of hake was a simple and clean dish, which I typically favour for lunch. Would have appreciated more greens though (and perhaps smaller greens, as the salad leaves were a bit big and hard to eat). My dining partner had the oven roasted chicken leg. We were impressed with the crispy skin and the soft, fall-off-the-bone meat on the chicken. The skin was light and crispy and had a nice seasoning to it. I actually really liked the bed of chopped carrots that the chicken was on. They looked deceptively like simple boiled carrots but were so tasty! All in all, lunch was very pleasant and we could see the effort that Chef Mok put into each dish. Service was friendly, in a homely way. That was nice but a little out of sync with the style and feel of the restaurant. We were served some home made bread which to be honest, tasted just that, and not in a good way. Location is a bit odd and not as trendy as some of the new and hip restaurants that have opened up recently in Singapore. All in all, while the food is good I think that the restaurant may need just a little bit more "oomph" to bring in the crowds. For now, I think people like exciting and new dishes and for the entire experience to be about more than just the food. The dishes here, while good, and the ingredients definitely shine, are a bit lacking in imagination and I just wished that the dining experience here was a bit more exciting.

If you're looking for unpretentious, good Cantonese food, this is the place. Manhill should actually be classified as an institution, as it must have stood at this very spot for over 40 years or so. I had just returned after a week in the US of A, and was craving warm rice and something tasty and soupy. So I suggested Manhill to the wife, who had never eaten here before. Called up my parents who immediately agreed to join. We were later debating how long it has been since we've been here. Certainly not since I've been married, as the wife and kids have never been here. We figured at least 30 years ago as we stopped coming here after we moved out from Pasir Panjang. But after all this time, this place did not disappoint, the food was as good as we remembered it. The sar pwor ngau lum (claypot beef brisket) was warming and tender at the same time. The j-hee pao kai  (paper wrapped chicken) was to die for. My 'ang mor kwan' kids ate up very every thing with no complaints. We had to order extra rice. In fact, the only complaints for the night was from the wife asking why I had never ever taken to this place. For sure, we'll be back again. Many times. Yum.

Eight stars pot with prawn, squid, sea cucumber, celery, carrot, mushroom, mustard, Chinese lettuce, bamboo shoots, shallot, fried garlic, pork slices, fried fish slices, baby corn braised in a comforting broth permeated with the earthen pot taste.
Chicken + 5-spice marinade + paper bag = goodness.  Something about that touch of anise and cinnamon will make you return without hesitation.

Wow. Manhill Restaurant was a rather serendipitous find. We were driving around trying to find some eatery and Mum suddenly piped up about giving Manhill a go instead and we were really glad we did!Manhill Restaurant serves old fashioned Cantonese dishes which I don't see elsewhere, and it's done in a really home-cooked style. We love the pork ribs, paper wrapped chicken and the 8-treasure claypot ... the sharksfin soup was not bad too. Quaint Chinese restaurant decor.Great place for a family dinner.

Manhill may not hawk the best cze-char, but the food passes muster and there's something to be said about the longevity of a restaurant in the cutthroat local F&B scene. Besides, Manhill does make for a lovely trip down nostalgia lane.We had:1) Paper-Wrapped Chicken ($26 at $13 for 6): a must-try, an ugly but delicious mess of chicken fat drippings and flavoursome juices.  2) Sauteed Chicken with Salt & Pepper ($15 for small): a simple stir-fry accented with oyster sauce - homestyled goodness.3) Claypot Beancurd ($15 for small): more delicate in flavour than expected, this had a good amount of cabbage and lettuce, rounded off with copious amounts of roasted garlic bubs.4) Prawn Omelette ($25 for medium): well done, with plenty of plump bouncy prawns, and a fragrant char.5) Chinese-Style Pork Ribs ($15 for small): scrumptious, with a mild honeyed frill to the sticky savoury marinade.6) Chilli Kangkong ($14 for medium): an aromatic hit of heady spice.

address: 40 Pasir Panjang Rd #02-37 Mapletree Business City Singapore 117383 Singapore
comment: A new concept store by the Cedele Group. Chiak serves up design your own grain and noodle bowls with your choice of proteins, sides, toppings and dressings. You can also chose from a selection of Signature bowls with preselected ingredients for those who are too lazy to customise their meal. You can add on a hot drink for an additional $1.20 (normally $2.40) or $1.70 (normally $2.90) for a cold drink. Upon entering, pick up an order sheet and pencil and choose your food items, then queue to pay for your items before collecting them. LOCATION 3.5/5This ~50 seater store is located on level 1 at the Food Park area with other eateries. Mapletree Business City is a bunch of office buildings so lunchtime will be crazy. You will see lunch crowds snaking all the way out the front door so it's best to arrive before 12pm if you want to get a seat. Most people would just takeaway their food and eat in the comfort of their offices. AMBIENCE 2/5Expect to either bring a megaphone or a pair of headphones if you want to talk or want some peace and quiet eating here. Decibel levels will be quite high during peak periods. FOOD 4/5The reason why people come here is for the tasty and healthy food options and also being able to customise their own grain or noodle bowls. OVERALL 3.5/5Overall a good place for food but best to come early if you don't want to wait for a table.

We came to have the lunch buffet here as it was under Burpple's one for one. We didn't know that it was the Hotel's restaurant so it was a pleasant surprise. It overlooks the hotel pool as well so it was a nice environment. We were always greeted with really friendly service staff which made the experience nice. I won't say that there is a large variety of food but it suffices for the scale of the restaurant. Wished there were more international choices though The food is good as well especially the carved meats that they have.

Never Judge a book by its cover. Tucked away in the middle of Alexandra Central Mall lies Sakagura, a tiny 26 seater restaurant that sells itself as a Japanese Dining Sake Bar. At a glance, it doesn't impress in any way. Simple, almost boring wooden tables and chairs, white walls with laminated pictures of their food. Even the menu is laminated with plastic ring binding.But once you get past the aesthetics, a whole different experience awaits!What they lack in aesthetics, was made up with some amazing and very affordable Japanese food!Chawanmushi with Uni ($8)The egg itself was perfectly seasoned and wonderfully steamed. It came with the usual suspects, ginko, Japanese fish cake, Crab stick and a small piece of chicken. In additional, there was a really fresh, really sweet piece of shrimp (tasted like a cooked Ama Ebi). Naturally I decided to pay a little more to have uni (Sea urchin) with mine. Wasn't expecting much but was very pleasantly surprised when I lofted the lid to reveal a generous amount of Uni on top of my egg. Rich, sweet and tasting like the sea, the robust flavour of the Uni matched the smooth, sweet egg perfectly. Gindara Mentai Bento ($22)Like any bento, you get the wonderfully little side dishes like salad, tofu, crispy fish skin but the star was definitely the Gindara. Not one but two generously thick pieces of Gindara, perfectly grilled. They were had the perfect amount of fat, making the fish soft, succulent and flaked apart easily while the mentaiko.... wow. The mentaiko was probably one of the best mentaikos we've ever had and it really help add the saltiness to the fish yet, at the same time, bringing out the sweetness of the Gindara. A very perfectly cooked dish. Chirashi Don ($18)My go to dish at any Japanese establishment.The chirashi came with Tamago yaki (1), Salmon (3), Salmon Belly (1), Maguro (2), Octopus (2), Hamachi (1), Mekajiki (1), Ebiko and Ikura. Sashimi slices were nice and thick and were very fresh. Not a hint of fishiness in any of the fish. The salmon belly was amazing, nearly melting in your mouth with each bite. I did feel that the rice had a tad bit too much vinegar and I'm not the biggest fan of that sweet, pink, powdery Sakura thing but overall it was still a very very good bowl of chirashi. We have to come back for their dinner as they seem to have triple the number of items as compared to lunch. So if you're looking to avoid a pretentiously expensive Japanese restaurant or steering away from those cheap knock-offs represented by a green frog than this place is a MUST visit!

As a California native, i was really happy to had been recommended John's pizza since Singapore pizza spots rarely fall under the American pizza category (plenty of Italian wine bar types around). The pizza is made to order and comes in 2 main forms: New York (thin) style, and deep dish. Since deep dish seemed like their signature, my boyfriend and I split the Jonh's 4 way. The edges were crispy from all the cheese fried in the pan, and the dough was thick but fluffy, retaining a good chewy texture. Only wish was there there were more of the sauce and toppings! Just because the crust was so thick, it felt like it could use a little more sauce on top.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Still just simply fantastic! The quality coming out of the kitchen remains consistently high, and I am always rewarded for my time and money over the many visits over many years to Blu Kouzina. The old classics that I always recommend remain satisfying and reflect the ethos of allowing quality ingredients to speak through the preparation and presentation. The Greek salad, saganaki with figs, pita with taramasalata, grilled xtopodi (octopus), lamb chops.   Other "must-trys" include the moussaka, stuffed grape leaves, and rice-stuffed garden vegetables.  I dearly love this place and I'm guessing you will too. Drop by and prove me wrong.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Very good greek food. Vegetarian friendly, wide range of options. Food is freshly prepared and service is just perfect. Interiors and decors were very nice and cozy. Got quite busy around 1pm. Outdoors is good, but inside was better for us to see the high roof, decors etc.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: If I were a teacher and the restaurant was a student I would give it a A+++ for everything. We came here for my sisters birthday today and the service was amazing, the staff was friendly to the highest level and the food was worth it, this spot is suitable of people of any age. I recommend coming to this restaurant for any special occasion as it is a little bit pricey.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: I loved the menu at Blu Kouzina. We ordered a range of plates to share and were very impressed by the flavours.  Authentic Greek food without any compromises.  The house prepared tzatziki was refreshing, perfectly accompanied by crispy pita bread.  The calamari was lightly fried and juicy.  The fattoush salad and salmon were delicate in taste and of excellent quality.  Plenty of beverages on offer too.  Apart from ouzo, you will find some of your favourites.  I particularly enjoyed the oversized Margarita, given the warmth of the day.Inside, the restaurant is presented like an old taverna with relics from Greece.  Welcoming and comforting yet airy,  plenty of space to make your party feel at home.The Dempsey Hill area itself is a great place to explore, with various galleries and antique shops.  A pleasant way to spend an afternoon in Singapore.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: We have been fans of Blu Kouzina since its beginning in Bukit Timah. The second incarnation at Dempsey was the peak. Everything at this new location, next door to the last one, is in every way a step down,except for the price!! The place is more cramped and more downmarket. The food is haphazard. Some dishes remain excellent, others not so. For instance, the lamb chops, while flavourful, are quite tough. Service staff are friendly, but a bit blurred and overzealous, keen to clear up the plates although we haven't finished the expensive dishes. At S$140 per pax at lunch, we thought it was poor value. For Mediterranean food, Pistachio at Wheelock Place is better AND better value. For us, Blu has moved from green light to red

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: On the pricey side... but consistently great food! Third time in two years, and it never disappoints. Today, fava bean deep and veg moussaka. Both amazing!Will be back for more!

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: It's so nice when a restaurant really cares about your experience. We've always loved the cuisine here and have never gone wrong with the menu or taking the waiters suggestions. This time we started with a wonderful bottle of Santorini white and wanted another wine to go with our final salad (light dinner night). The bottle we were recommended was absolutely delicious, but just not a good fit with our meal. We politely spoke to the manager about this and he was incredibly accommodating about recommending the perfect glass of white wine that was a superb pairing. The restaurant more than made up for the mistake and the service was great throughout the meal. We appreciate the care the entire staff puts into the experience of the patrons, we will definitely be happy to return. Thank you!

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Huge fan since their old days in Bukit Timah area (I think it was there before).Visited two days in a row in this Dempsey location and was blown away. I definitely didn't think I would get this kind of Mediterranean food in Singapore with excellent choices of Greek wine. The service is prompt and friendly with a perfect ambiance to feel like it's a sharing type restaurant. Very Mediterranean feel!I had their chicken skewers with hummus and french fries which was a great choice. The flavor of the chicken was amazing, very moist and delicious.The second day I tried both their chicken and beef shwarmas which I wouldn't quite recommend as much as the skewers.Highly recommend for a great Mediterranean meal in Singapore.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: 4.5 stars. Greek food at Dempsey Hill. Serves very good Greek grills here - had the lamb and chicken kebab - both were very good. The wrap is also excellent - juicy meat with complementary hummus and veggies. Portions are huge - best if you go with a group and sample various things. A bit expensive but worth it.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Very rare you have an experience when you want to go back to the same restaurant to eat... and this is one of them. Beautiful decor and ambience. Polite and helpful staff. Even though they do not have kids menu to go with but the place is kid's friendly. Food is perfect to meet your palate. We ordered their signature dips, salad with olives,onions, feta and cherry tomatoes, feta psiti, and a meat platter to share. Ingredients were fresh and flavors were uniquely blended to bring out the taste of each ingredient and the spices used to cook the dishes. And wine  paired perfectly  to go with our choices of food selection. This place is definitely a must visit.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: I adore what they did with their new interior! Beautiful setting and delicious, authentic Greek food. I personally really like the dakos salad. The kalamaki was alright. Almost brings me back to summers I'd spent in Greece! Only complaint is that the dining area in the back that was designed to be a glasshouse of sorts feels like one, too - when the sun's out it's a sauna in there.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Excellent place for a light or heavy lunch. We were here for dinner earlier this week and loved it so much that we came back for lunch. If it's Greek you want in Singapore, this is the place.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: We had the pleasure of dining at Blu Kouzina while visiting our expat friends on Singapore. We shared family style and it was some of the best Greek food I've had outside of Greece! The tzatziki, hummus and pita were great to start. We shared a chicken pita, steak and the grilled octopus. Hands down the best octopus I've ever had, it will be very difficult to top. I hope to dine here again on my next visit this beautiful country!

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Best Greek restaurant in Singapore. Service is consistently good and the food is great.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Though a bit pricey it is the best Greek food that can be found in Singapore. Much of it reminds me of home cooked style that my mom used to make.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Hands down the best Greek restaurant in Singapore. They moved from Bukit Timah to Dempsey and in my opinion, upped their game. Food and presentation have greatly improved. We preferred vegetarian options to their meats. Having said that, the lamb chops was divine. Waitstaff stellar. Prices a tad high. Will be back again and again.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Just moved to SG and been craving Greek food for a while. This was the first Mediterranean restaurant we've been to in town. Exceeded my expectations. The Greek salad was just absolutely perfect. As well as the sea bream! Definitely going to be a regular once we get settled here! Hope they keep everything the same.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: My Favourite restaurant in Singapore. The food is super fresh and the service is great!

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Loved the interior decor, but the food was sadly not as good as the previous times at the older location. The appetizers were great, but the meat was a bit tough and lacking flavor. In any event, book in advance because there's always a waitlist and they are almost impossible to reach by phone.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: Delicious Greek food in Singapore. It was a little pricey but we thoroughly enjoyed our food. We split a Greek salad and Eggplant Moussaka. It tasted almost like a sherperd's pie with Eggplant and was beyond good. Complimentary bread was tasty as well. Definitely plan to return.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: First time trying this place! I'm not exactly a big Greek food fan, but food was great! Totally impressed with the setup! Amazing service!!

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: We went for dinner to celebrate my husband's birthday. The setting is beautiful and the service impeccable.The food is amazing and portion sizes are good for sharing. We ordered a variety of appetizers and were so full that we went straight to desserts then !!!They even brought a beautiful dessert with a candle for my husband,We would definitely recommend this place for authentic and delicious Greek food !

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: I love Greek food, love love love it.  I had been hearing about Blu Kouzina since I moved to SG, and my work colleague had been raving about it forever.  It was a friend birthday, so I thought, Blu Kouzina sounds like a good choice.  Made the reservation online (super easy) A little hard to find unless you know where you're going, but grab cab managed to find it.  We were seated at a tiny table way in the back, practically outside the place, which was okay I guess.  I noticed many large groups.  The decor is very pretty, almost reminded me of a beach place you would find in the Hamptons.  Service initially was a little slow, we had a white Greek wine that was decent, $67, and started with some meatballs which were way overcooked.  The prices here are not what I would call reasonable, although i realize nothing in Singapore really is, this felt a little inflated.  $29 for 3 little lamb chops and some soggy grilled zucchini.  :(  Friend had the pita which he said wasn't great.  The fries I did enjoy, LOL   The bread was cold and hard, but the olive oil was enjoyable. I asked for medium well lamb, it was well done.  My friend asked for well done meat, his was well done.   Personally I've had much much much better Greek food, at much more reasonable prices.  They did bring out a dessert with a candle, which was delicious.  Nice enough service, but I think I can find better.

address: 10 Dempsey Rd #01-21, Dempsey Hill Singapore 247700 Singapore
comment: The place was packed at the new Dempsey location on Saturday night, but the servers were friendly and has suggested a great bottle of wine and helped us with some of the vegan requirements from us too.  The saganaki was amazing, grilled lamb was also nice.  The portion is small so it's good to order bunch.  I'd love to come back and try their seafood next time.

The hippest, most happening destination in Singapore right now. Tons of restaurants, cafes that were transformed from old British barracks. The area has Tons of history, esp during WWII. Check out The White Rabbit, a refurbished British chapel that is now a brunch hotspot

Great area with many restaurants and breweries. Most of them have beautiful settings with green backdrops. The area is a little pricey and a regular hangout for expats. It's a good spot for a quiet dinner and drinks afterward.

Dempsey Hill remains my choice of destination for brunch or a chill out afternoon because of one main factor: FREE PARKING (please don't ever take that away!). It's a bit out of the way and a pain to get to if you don't drive, but drivers (and me) love this spot because you never have to worry about paying an arm and a leg just for your car.Sometimes parking is rather tight in the main lots, but if you don't mind walking a little, there is usually a parking spot in some of the less crowded clusters. The main Dempsey Road can also get a tad crowded so here's a hint: Minden Road leads you to the area just fine and is usually less used...There's also a great selection of dining places so if it gets crowded, it's easy to just walk to the next spot. My usual choices to visit up here include House, Jones the Grocer and Wine Company.
Expat paradise or so it seems, lots of choices for dinner or lunch.  Great antique shops and quirky cool shops and my favorite rug shop in all of Singapore lotto carpets.

A former British Army Camp, Dempsey Hill is harder for people without cars to get to, even though it's just a few minutes away from the Botanical Garden and Holland Village or Orchard Road. It's known for great food, though (sigh) sadly in my case, most are not halal. I like going to Dempsey Hill just to chill though. I can enjoy my ice-cream in peace at the Ben & Jerry's branch down here, head to Culina and Jones The Grocer to buy freshly baked bread and look at what produce is in season. I like the selections at Beauty Emporium at House too.Antique, Asian furniture is available at several shops here, but they're pricey. Families may also wish to let their kids loose at Go-Go Bambini. They have a huge ball pit and indoor playground that kids love. They also have a café for visitors to relax, chit-chat and try out the cakes and muffins they serve.Many shops close by 6.30pm, but still, Dempsey Hill's s nice place to hang out over the weekend. To me, it's even better when there are less crowds on weekdays.

Dempsey Hill is one of my favorite places to go for dinner. The place has been completely revamped from the old days, when it was old army barracks. Now in place are trendy bars and restaurants and some furniture and specialty stores. Its frequented by lots of expats, yuppies and trendy locals. My favorite places to go here would be PS Café and Margaritas. Restaurants can be a bit pricey, but not what you wouldn't expect in other restaurants around the area. A nice place to grab a drink at bar, then walk over for dinner in a nice restaurant. It can be a bit tricky to get here though, unless you drive or take a cab; as its up a hill and no buses or trains come directly here.

Dempsey Hill, a great place to retreat to after a long day of shopping or a place to have brunch before you hit the town.  Surrounded by lush greenery, Dempsey Hill houses many modern bistros ranging from western to Asian food, even local flavors like the famous chili crab (Jumbo Seafood). Another great thing about this location is the free parking! Nothing comes for free, not in Singapore at least so with FREE parking offered, this place is a winner with everyone! Before the F&B culture took over Dempsey, the place was known for niche antique/outdoor furniture retailers so if you're looking to add a unique piece of furniture to your home, this is your go to place . Feel free to enjoy a cup of coffee while hunting for furniture!

The perfect location for a good catch up/ gathering. Especially with the delicious hearty meal served in a retro-filled cafe! Great service and people that made us feel so welcome. It was a sumptous meal with finger foods like the cripsy drumlets and waffle fries with cheese, mayo and BBQ sauce. Definitely satisfied my palate!

OMG So delicious! Menu changes slightly but men Loved their burgers, I had the salmon with spicy noodles So good, and friend had the Roasted Chicken with a Salt Carmel Glaze, she said was excellent.This privately owned establishment was affordable, cozy/cool/indoor and outdoor ( under roof) seating. Hip, cleaver, nostalgic... must go, was So worth it!!

A Good Habit To Pick-Up!Tucked away on top of a hill in Telok Blangah Rise is Old Habits.Opened by a husband and wife team, Old Habits is part museum, part cafe, part antique store. The feel of the area itself brings you back a few decades, with only a small market and a few shops serving this quiet community. First impression? Old Habit brings back even more nostalgia with their old outdoor seating area. Made up of vintage clam shell chairs, you would have expected a couple of old uncles in singlets to be asleep on the chairs, if not for the bright lights of the cafe.Opening the door, we were expecting to be hit by a wave of muskiness from the old items on display but was pleasantly surprised when the place smelt pretty.... Good! If you're looking for a fun antique items to buy than this is the place for you! Old telephones, photos, textbooks, comics, you name it, they have it. It's like being a 5 year old again. With their extensive collection of view finders / view masters, it was hours of  fun going through everything they had to offer and the best part? Almost everything's for sale!Now to the food. A simple menu made up of around 5-6 items per category (Appetizers, mains etc), "Old Habit" chooses to keep it simple and manageable, ensuring that by not over stretching themselves with an overly extensive menu, they will not sacrifice the quality of the food being served.Drinks: Lemon Lime Float & CoCo Melaka What better way to add to the nostalgia of the cafe than with a drink that reminds us of the past. Well thought through and re-created, the Lemon Lime Float tastes exactly like Solero, a lime and vanilla ice cream that I'm sure many of us LOVED while we were younger. A perfect drink for a really really hot day! The CoCo Melaka Soda was a nice twist. Coconut juice, with a hint of Gula Melaka topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. The Gula Melaka adds a nice richness n sweetness to an otherwise ordinary drink and even helps in bringing out the sweetness and fragrance of the coconut juice. Spaghetti Carbonara. Will I ever learn my lesson? Ordering Carbonaras even though I see the words "creamy". I'm proud to finally say that, this carbonara is pretty darn good! Unlike most Carbonaras, we could actually taste the eggs in the sauce. The sauce was rich, eggy and so delicious! Pasta was al Dante and that sprinkle of chilli powder gave it an extra kick. Only thing is lacked was a good sprinkle of parmesan to give is that sharpness but overall, definitely one the nicest we've had under $15.00.Jessy's Spicy CasseroleNow this was an interesting twist! Unlike the normal Shepard's Pie, this was done with a chicken chunks marinated in a Nonya sauce. The initial scoop felt a little disappointing, with the lack of gravy and meat, but as we slowly dug in, revealing the juicy pieces of chicken, we soon realised that a gravy wasn't really needed! The nonya sauce or marinade used was so tasty! And the mashed used had a hint of curry powder which added to the fragrance of the dish, elevating the potatoes to a whole different level of yumness.This was a very well constructed dish that turned an otherwise ordinary shepherd's pie into something a little more local. Coconut kueh with Vanilla Ice cream. What a way to end our meal with this delicious dessert! With crunchy coconut flakes prominent in the kueh, this felt like an Asian take on a bread and butter pudding. The fragrant smell of toasted coconut flakes mixed with the sweetness from the ice cream and the slight saltiness from kueh makes this an absolute delight to have. Overall, this place is fantastic, with the owners taking the time to slowly show you some of the cool toys they have available. They're friendly and very welcoming and you can tell that they have the dedication and passion to keep this place going, ensuring that whether you're 6 or 60, you'll feel like a kid again once you step through the doors of Old Habits.

Interesting and cosy cafe tucked in a quiet housing estate. Excellent service and food by the husband and wife team. Food is reasonably priced and value for money. Also, the cafe is a museum hence there is lots to explore and it is a walk down memory lane.
